brief_summary.textblock:
Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) has been reported in up to 85% of all infants born
      prematurely, and has been associated with a wide range of symptoms.  These include
      irritability, pauses in breathing, heart rate drops, declines in oxygen levels, chronic lung
      disease, and delays in growth and development.  A novel approach to the mangement of GERD in
      infants is the use of an abdominal band, applying gentle pressure and possibly reducing the
      reflux of acid from the stomach.  The purpose of this study is to evaluate the impact of a
      swaddle blanket with an abdominal band insert on the incidence of infant apnea, bradycardia,
      oxygen declines, and pH (acid) changes.

clinical_study.brief_title: Impact of Swaddle Blanket on Gastroesophageal Reflux

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

        - NICU patients who have a 5 channel study requested by the attending neonatologist  -

        Exclusion Criteria:

        -

intervention.description: Two arms involve varying time spent in blanket

clinical_study.official_title: Impact of Swaddle Blanket on Gastroesophageal Reflux

other_outcome.description: all heart rate drops below 80 beats per minute will be noted
all oxygen drops below 92% will be noted

primary_outcome.description: all epochs of pH values below 4.0 will be measured

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: all breathing pauses greater than 20 seconds will be noted

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Prevention
